prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this question. The user is asking whether the person (the author) is in the wrong for wanting their girlfriend to start paying some bills after a single incident. The situation is that they live together, he pays all the bills because she only works part-time. The incident was about takeout costing under $40 where she was upset when he asked her to pay. Now he's considering making her contribute more, even though he acknowledges she can't pay much.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The author is frustrated because he's shouldering all financial responsibilities, which is common in many relationships when one partner earns less. The incident with the takeout was a small amount, but it seems to have been a catalyst for his frustration. He feels that even though it's just one instance, it's time for her to start contributing. 

From the author's perspective, it's about fairness and principle. He's paying everything, and this incident made him realize he wants her to share the load, even if it's minimal. But is it fair to make her pay just because of that one incident? Maybe he's using that as an excuse to address a longer-standing issue. However, the key point here is whether the action is justified. 

On the other hand, the girlfriend works part-time, so her financial situation is limited. The author acknowledges that she can't pay much of the bills, so expecting her to take on more might be unrealistic unless there's a significant change in her income. The incident over $40 could be seen as trivial, but it's the principle that's bothering him. 

In relationships, communication is key. Instead of making a sudden demand after one incident, maybe a discussion about financial responsibilities would be better. However, the question is about whether the author is in the wrong for wanting her to pay some bills. If his intention is to start sharing expenses based on her ability, that might be reasonable. But if he's making her pay a large portion despite her limited income, that's another matter. The text says "she wouldn't be able to pay a lot of the bills," so he's aware of her limitations. 

He's asking if he's in the wrong. The answer hinges on whether his action is fair. Since it's a small incident and he's considering her financial situation, it might not be entirely his fault. However, using a single incident to justify changing shared financial responsibilities might be abrupt. But again, it's about principle for him. 

I need to weigh if his approach is reasonable. Maybe he's right in wanting her to contribute what she can, but the way he's approaching it (after one incident) might be hasty. But the question isn't about the approach, it's about being in the wrong. If he's not making her pay a lot and just wants her to start with some, considering her earnings, then maybe he's not in the wrong. 

So, answer B (No) because he's addressing the need for shared responsibility and considering her income, even if the trigger was a small incident.
